editionStmt.edition: Digital catalogue using the TEI P5 metadata schema

head.title: Tegernsee miscellany. Excerptum de astrologia and De ordine ac positione stellarum

msItem.incipit:
I De quadrifario dei opere
II De mundi formatione
msItem.finalRubric: expliciunt capitula libri de naturis rerum

msItem.note: Initially left blank. Later filling texts: short medical recipes.

msItem.incipit: Naturas rerum uarias labentis et aeui
msItem.explicit: atque inde affrica a meridie usque ad occidentem extenditur.
msItem.note: Full text with ample glosses on the outer and upper margine.

msItem.incipit: Locus huius artis hurimuda uel exalrasse uel girum. Persona bridualt uel beda
msItem.explicit: A septentrionibus triones uel teriones grece boues dicuntur eo quod viitem stellae in plaustro videntur septentrio dicitur.

msItem.author: Calcidius
msItem.title: Translation of Plato's Timeus
msItem.incipit: Socrates in exhortationibus suius uirtutem laudans
msItem.explicit: exaequatae nature temporis sotia natura nancisceretur imaginem.

msItem.note: Later filling text: short medical recipes.
msItem.incipit: Antidatum quod stomacho prodest et uentrem sine conturbatione soluet

msItem.title: Excerptum de astrologia
msItem.incipit: Duo sunt extremi uertices mundi quos appelant polos septentrionis et austri
msItem.decoNote: An unfinished drawing of a planisphere at the top left of f. 25v.

msItem.title: De ordine ac positione
msItem.incipit: Est quidem hic ordo et positio siderum quae fixa caelo
msItem.decoNote: Drawings of the constellations around and within the text. (The images seem to have been drawn before the text was written). The stars are marked with red dots but only on f. 27r-v. Blank space left for initials at the beginning of sections.

msItem.author: Ausonius
msItem.title: Ad boreae partes
msItem.note: With musical notation above the letters.

msItem.author: (Ps?)Jerome
msItem.title: Epistola ad Dardanum
msItem.rubric: Epistula hieronimi ad dardanum de generibus musicorum incipit cum interrogatione sua
msItem.incipit: Cogor a te ut ti dardane de aliis generibus musicorum sicut res docer
msItem.explicit: intellegenda sunt si terrena sapienter ac diligenter respiciamus spiritualiter ac mystice in

msItem.incipit: Decanus sub centurione Sub tribune centurio
msItem.explicit: et super quem unum annum donat ne elation subripiat
msItem.filiation: This just few lines long text follows Jerom’s letter also in Florence MS Laurentiana Plut. XXIX Cod. 32 from the 9th-10th c

msItem.author: Berno of Reichenau
msItem.title: Ratio generalis de initio adventus domini
msItem.incipit: Sciendum sane est et omnibus orthodoxis fidelibus memoriter retinendum
msItem.explicit: unum batisma sit et una ęcclesię unanimitas. AMEN

layout.p: On ff. 1r-31v and on f. 100v there are around 26 ruled lines in one column;
on ff. 32r-100r andff. 101r-102v there are between 25 and 32 ruled lines in two columns.

binding.p: Binding with four bosses and a strap-and-pin mechanism with the pin on the upper board.

accMat.p: Paper sheet from the 15th c. content notebound in the MS between first and second folio.
Paste down 13th c. hymns attributed to Ambrose Hinc roma celsum uerticem and others.
F. Ir-v and f. I*r-v liturgical hymns with neums O sator rerum reparator cui christe rex regum metuende censor ad preces nostras
On the back pastedown unidentified text.

provenance.p: The manuscript is supposed to be copied in part by Abbot Ellinger of Tegernsee Abbey (975/980-1056), as it is stated in a note on fol. 103v Abbas indignus ego Ellinger peccator istam glosam scripsi dum essem in Altahensi monasterio deo sanctoque quirino. Rogo uos omnes in ea legentes ut oretis pro me. which however is an indication only that he copied De verborum significatione and the following shorter texts, and not necessarily the whole manuscript.

It belong to the Tegernsee Abbey as noted on the first flyleaf Istud volumen attinet venerabili monasterio sancti Quirini in Tegernsee H̃ Abbas Ellingerus scripsit hunc librum. Additionally there is a note from the librarian of the monastery Ambrosius Schwerzenbeck on the small paper leaf fol. 1-bis from the 15th c. This together with the notes and glosses written by Abbot Ellinger suggests that the manuscript in its current composition was procured by the Abbot for the use of his community around the first half of the 11th c. in Tegernsee. The manuscript is recorded in the 15th c. catalogue among Bede's works under the title Excerptum de naturalibus hystoriis Plinii philosophi with the signature l 44.

listBibl.head: Selected Bibliography:
listBibl.bibl: Eastwood, Bruce Stansfield. "Calcidius’s Commentary on Plato’s‘Timaeus’ in Latin Astronomy of the Ninth to Eleventh Centuries." In Eastwood, The Revival of Planetary Astronomy in Carolingian and Post-Carolingian Europe, 171–209, 2002. p. 173.
Eder, Christine Elisabeth. Die Schule Des Klosters Tegernsee Im Frühen Mittelalter Im Spiegel der Tegernseer Handschriften. Munich: Universität München, 1972. pp. 78-9.
Glauche, Günter, Hermann Knaus, and Bernhard Bischoff. Mittelalterliche Bibliothekskataloge Deutschlands und Der Schweiz. Bd. 4, 2: Bistum Freising. München, 1979.
Bergmann, Rolf et al., Katalog der althochdeutschen und altsächsischen Glossenhandschriften, Berlin/New York 2005, Vol. 1, pp. 158-. (Nr. 18).
